Don't like pellet grills, I've tried multiple types of pellets, they all are sub par. Spent about $300 on a pellet grill, was very excited, love to BBQ and been consistently underwhelmed.

They work to cook, but they don't smoke well, they give the appearance of smoke but lack the smoke flavor. They do smoke, just at a very slow rate, so you need to cook the meat longer, which dries it out.

Offset smokers generally do it better, and their priced competitively to a pellet grill. There is more work to it, but the final product is superior in my opinion. I've seen gas grills with small wood chip burners which smoke better than basically every pellet grill I've tried.

Offsets give a more charcoal taste too, along with the smoke, where as pellets kinda come off as a gas grill. Just heat, no flavor, and I think that's due to very low quality pellets honestly. Yet it remains consistent for basically all the brands I've tried.

Alternative fuel to gas

i had to work at a wood pellet mill before and oh man did it not look as clean as this. the place was basically two "hangar tents" with all the machinery operating inside it, no insulation to keep us warm so we had to work with heavy coats. We had an operator and two baggers that basically bagged and stacked the finished pellets. sawdust piling up in the corners, machinery held together by duct tape and hope, on a freezing wet day you had to go pound on the side of the bin that feeds the wood chips into the grinder with a sledgehammer to knock the material lose, i had to put out a small fire in the corner by the "office" once, eventually started getting shorted on hours because of critical machine malfunctions eventually had to quit and move out cause there was literally NOTHING close enough to work at. Awful, horrible job that also damaged my body having to work at. but apparently the company decided to keep it running as is instead of upgrading the equipment or shutting it down for a while despite having other facilities that were run to a much higher standard and much less dangerously and this one not having as good of an output. And because it was operating in a dead end small mountain town they could get away with letting sawdust float over the town when we inevitably got a strong wind blowing through the valley.
A lot of energy...😱

3:40 I'm like 99% sure lignin =/= tree sap. Lignin is the "bulk" of the trees structure / physical material. Sap is basically tree food - nutrients that gets produced by sap wood and moved to the branches to help produce new branches and leaves.

I think this sentence should be "The compression generates heat which draws out the tree sap still contain in the wood fiber made mostly of lignin. Once the sap cools it helps the wood pellets keep their shape"

These pellets are so stupid. My place is heated by a heat pump and by a wood pellet stove. So when the power went out I was basically out of luck. Wood pellet stoves require electricity to work. Not just to start but to operate continuously. I really wish the place had a regular wood stove in stove. I could have been nice and warm during the power outage instead I froze for 36 hours. I don't see the point in a wood stove that doesn't burn random bits of wood and also requires electricity. Talk about pointless over engineering.

Qoute :
The U.S. exported 635,463.4 metric tons of wood pellets in April, down from 667,309 metric tons in March, but up from 595,166.2 metric tons in April 2020, according to data released by the USDA Foreign Agricultural Service on June 8.

The U.S. exported wood pellets to approximately 16 countries during April. The U.K. was the top destination at 519,144.4 metric tons, followed by the Netherlands at 91,050.3 metric tons and the French West Indies at 21,733.9 metric tons.

I have a diesel powered pellet maker and can make all the pellets I need in one Summer to heat my home in the Winter for several years. Of course when we first started using our pellet stove the pellet prices where we live were quite expensive and it was cheaper to use Natural Gas. I get all the saw dust I could ever need for free from one of our local cabinet shops, no grinding needed. I just make sure the moisture content is at 12% and I can make around 400 lbs of pellets an hour.

I’m about to tick some of you off, but before I do let me say that I have a pellet grill. Pellet grills do NOT produce the same kind of smoke as an actual smoker. This video explains why. They take all the moisture out of the pellets. Moisture plays a huge part in what kind of smoke comes out when cooking with real wood and hugely affects flavor. Can you get a decent result with a pellet grill? Yes, but it is not true smoke flavor. I don’t care what you say. You might get a smoke ring (which is just a chemical reaction) but it does not flavor food the same was as actual wood does. Fight me on it.
